awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: The social brain: behavioral, neural, and transcriptomic modulation of the brain
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Animals interact with their world through cognitive mechanisms, the substrates of which are found in the neural tissues of the central nervous system. A fundamental mechanism of cognition is associative learning where an individual associates a stimulus with a specific experience. Animals form many associations about events in their world, including negative events such as the avoidance of predators or extreme conditions and positive events such as the location of food or mates. Depending on how an individual reacts to stress, positive and negative learning contexts likely affect individuals in different ways. Using zebrafish as a model, this research aims to understand how fish with differing stress reactivity react to different learning contexts, and how this differentially affects their brain. The project will create public outreach opportunities to diverse audiences in association with this work.

This research will utilize cutting edge behavioral analysis and neuromolecular techniques to probe the behavioral, neural, and transcriptomic outcomes of different learning contexts. Using zebrafish from lines selected for high (reactive) and low (proactive) stress reactivity, the Fellow will train fish in a conditioned place preference paradigm using appetitive or aversive stimuli. Following the experiment, neural activation will be evaluated using the immediate early gene egr-1 and expression of the plasticity-related gene npas4a across a network of brain regions involved in learning and memory. The Fellow will then evaluate the neural transcriptome in the hippocampus and basolateral amygdala. The Fellow will compare learning and memory, neural activation, and gene expression between learning contexts (appetitive or aversive) and stress coping styles (reactive or proactive) to determine how intrinsic and extrinsic factors interact in individual fish to affect cognition at the behavioral, neural, and transcriptomic level. This fellowship will provide opportunities for the Fellow to develop research, teaching, and public engagement skills that will prepare them to begin an independent career at a research-intensive institution. The Fellow will engage diverse communities with STEM through public outreach and cultivate valuable research opportunities for students from local community colleges.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Associative learning is ubiquitous across animals, being observed in nearly every species studied to date. This learning mechanism enables organisms to learn associations between different stimuli or events occurring in their environment. For example, an individual may learn an association between a particular location and either a positive food reward or negative risk from a dangerous predator. These types of associations are regularly formed by animals learning about their environment. The nature of these associations varies depending on how positive or negative an individual perceives that stimulus.

The goal of this project was to understand the behavioral, neural, and genomic mechanisms associated with learning positive and negative stimuli in zebrafish with differing stress coping styles. An individual’s stress coping style describes how it consistently reacts to stimuli in its environment, what you could also refer to as “personality.” Individuals that have a proactive coping style tend to be bold, show a lower stress response, and have less flexibility in their behavior. Individuals that have a reactive coping style tend to be shy, show a greater stress response, and have greater flexibility in their behavior. These coping styles exist on a continuum in nature; however, in our lab, we have bred two strains of zebrafish to be consistently proactive or consistently reactive. For this project, I ran zebrafish from each of these lines through two learning and memory assays. In one assay I used a positive reward to train them and in the other I used a negative punishment. So far, I found that proactive fish learn the association with the positive reward faster than reactive fish. This likely stems from the proactive fish being less risk averse and taking quick advantage of the reward offered to them in the new environment. The next step is to train fish in the negative punishment assay. I will then compare the expression of different genes in the brains of these fish to understand what neural differences lead to these differences in learning.

In addition to these research activities, I also dedicated my time to engaging local Nebraska citizens with my research. I did this in multiple ways. First, I worked with a program on campus called NE STEM 4 U to create four neuroscience activities for elementary and middle school students. These activities are currently being used in after school programs in the Omaha area, connecting students with concepts related to behavior, neuroscience, and genomics. I presented another set of activities at the Nebraska Science Festival in 2022 and 2023, which engaged students and adults alike in the Omaha area. Finally, I presented my research to adult audiences at two science café events in Nebraska. These activities engaged many Nebraska citizens of different ages in the work I was doing.

Finally, I dedicated time to mentoring undergraduates from backgrounds underrepresented in science. I worked with a total of 8 students during my time at the University of Nebraska Omaha, working with them in research and professional development. I worked with my students to give them the skills necessary to succeed in STEM, encouraging these students to pursue a future career in STEM. These activities enabled me to continue developing as an academic scientist and I will utilize these skills in my new position as an Assistant Professor at a primarily undergraduate institution.  

 


Last Modified: 11/07/2023
Modified by: Levi Storks
